update.description:
This PR presents the initial implementation of the Feature System. ~~I'm labeling it a WIP because I still want to add some more concrete tests and examples for how features work, but the implementation is finished, and I think it's safe to begin reviewing.~~

Note that this is the **FeatureSystem\_raw** branch. The old `FeatureSystem` branch was a prototype which is being discarded \(although it played a big role in getting this branch to where it is\).

I recommend looking at `Feature_TEST.cc` to get a quick high-level glimpse of what the Feature System is trying to achieve. There are three mock "features": `EngineMockFeature`, `LinkMockFeature`, and `SecondLinkMockFeature`. Each of these defines a function within a nested class \(`Engine` or `Link`\). We create a `FeatureList` which combines all these features, and then use `Engine3d` and `Link3d` to extract and combine their APIs. As a result, `Link3d<MockList>` contains both of the functions defined in `LinkMockFeature` and `SecondLinkMockFeature`.

~~My next step will be to add more concrete and illustrative tests to~~ `Feature_TEST.cc`.

To see a full-fledged test use of the Feature System, see `test/integration/FeatureSystem.cc`.
update.title: Feature System Part 1

content.html: https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-pr-win/28/

content.raw:
the windows build is now unstable, with just a few compiler warnings:

[![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ign_physics-pr-win&build=21)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-pr-win/21/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-pr-win/21/warningsResult/

Some of those are from ign-common (which will be fixed by [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/150/image_testcc-mark-arguments-to-color/diff)), but there is one complaint about a DLL interface for a shared pointer in the Identity.hh file. Usually we suppress those warnings, but I'll wait for confirmation from @mxgrey before doing so because I'm not sure when it's ok or not to do that.
content.html:
the windows build is now unstable, with just a few compiler warnings:

https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_physics-pr-win/21/warningsResult/

Some of those are from ign-common (which will be fixed by this PR), but there is one complaint about a DLL interface for a shared pointer in the Identity.hh file. Usually we suppress those warnings, but I'll wait for confirmation from @mxgrey before doing so because I'm not sure when it's ok or not to do that.

content.raw: this is no longer a problem
content.html: this is no longer a problem

content.raw: It might actually be in a comment discussion within the design doc, I’m not sure. Either way, it does deserve its own standalone section, because the connection between SDF and plugins is a very important detail.
content.html: It might actually be in a comment discussion within the design doc, I’m not sure. Either way, it does deserve its own standalone section, because the connection between SDF and plugins is a very important detail.

content.raw: Ok, I'll take another look at the design document
content.html: Ok, I'll take another look at the design document

content.raw:
Right, I think the design doc touches on this a bit, but here’s the brief overview:

1. We'll pre-define some standard feature sets. When a user loads a plugin that uses one of these standard feature sets, we'll be able to detect it using `plugin->QueryInterface<T>()` and then pass the plugin an object which expresses that standard set of features.
2. Users who want a custom set of features will need to have their plugin accept a generic object that doesn't express any features, and then we'll provide some "dynamic casting" tools \(similar to `RequestFeatures` which has already been implemented\) to convert the generic object into an object that expresses the custom features that the user’s plugin requires. If that “dynamic cast” fails, then it falls on the user’s plugin to decide how to proceed.

In both cases, we don’t need the SDF to tell us what features are required, because in case \(1\) we can detect it from the interfaces provided by the plugin, and in case \(2\) we rely on the user’s plugin to extract the features that it needs.

`ign-gazebo` shouldn't need any knowledge about physics features, because that will all be handled within `ign-physics` and `ign-plugin`.
content.html:
Right, I think the design doc touches on this a bit, but here’s the brief overview:

  1. We'll pre-define some standard feature sets. When a user loads a plugin that uses one of these standard feature sets, we'll be able to detect it using plugin->QueryInterface<T>() and then pass the plugin an object which expresses that standard set of features.
  2. Users who want a custom set of features will need to have their plugin accept a generic object that doesn't express any features, and then we'll provide some "dynamic casting" tools (similar to RequestFeatures which has already been implemented) to convert the generic object into an object that expresses the custom features that the user’s plugin requires. If that “dynamic cast” fails, then it falls on the user’s plugin to decide how to proceed.

In both cases, we don’t need the SDF to tell us what features are required, because in case (1) we can detect it from the interfaces provided by the plugin, and in case (2) we rely on the user’s plugin to extract the features that it needs.

ign-gazebo shouldn't need any knowledge about physics features, because that will all be handled within ign-physics and ign-plugin.

content.raw:
So far I've mainly been thinking about this feature system from the perspective of the interface for physics plugin providers, and this does a great job with that interface.

As I think about it from the other side of the interface, such a user of `ign-gazebo` who wants to load a xml model / world file and then call ign-physics, I'm wondering how much knowledge `ign-gazebo` is required to have about all these features. Would a world file be able to list required features in text format? Currently, FeatureLists just supports symbols as a template parameter.
content.html:
So far I've mainly been thinking about this feature system from the perspective of the interface for physics plugin providers, and this does a great job with that interface.

As I think about it from the other side of the interface, such a user of ign-gazebo who wants to load a xml model / world file and then call ign-physics, I'm wondering how much knowledge ign-gazebo is required to have about all these features. Would a world file be able to list required features in text format? Currently, FeatureLists just supports symbols as a template parameter.

content.raw:
This PR is ready to use `ign-plugin`, but it depends on four PRs:

1. [Core directories](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/100/)
2. [Warning suppression](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/101/)
3. [Porting to ign-plugin](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/pull-requests/1/)
4. [Enhancements to plugin features](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/pull-requests/2)

Those PRs are admittedly enormous, but I think the changes will be worthwhile. Tomorrow I’ll see about breaking them down further.
content.html:
This PR is ready to use ign-plugin, but it depends on four PRs:

  1. Core directories
  2. Warning suppression
  3. Porting to ign-plugin
  4. Enhancements to plugin features

Those PRs are admittedly enormous, but I think the changes will be worthwhile. Tomorrow I’ll see about breaking them down further.

Note that this is the **FeatureSystem_raw** branch. The old `FeatureSystem` branch was a prototype which is being discarded (although it played a big role in getting this branch to where it is).

I recommend looking at `Feature_TEST.cc` to get a quick high-level glimpse of what the Feature System is trying to achieve. There are three mock "features": `EngineMockFeature`, `LinkMockFeature`, and `SecondLinkMockFeature`. Each of these defines a function within a nested class (`Engine` or `Link`). We create a `FeatureList` which combines all these features, and then use `Engine3d` and `Link3d`  to extract and combine their APIs. As a result, `Link3d<MockList>` contains both of the functions defined in `LinkMockFeature` and `SecondLinkMockFeature`.

~~My next step will be to add more concrete and illustrative tests to `Feature_TEST.cc`.~~

To see a full-fledged test use of the Feature System, see `test/integration/FeatureSystem.cc`.

content.raw:
no problem, and I'll clarify further: I'll approve when our Jenkins CI builds are ready

* ubuntu can build ign-plugin from source if we make a release-tools PR
* homebrew will need a ign-plugin formula
* windows will probably need an update to the gazebodistro file: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebodistro/src/default/ign-physics0.yaml
content.html:
no problem, and I'll clarify further: I'll approve when our Jenkins CI builds are ready

  • ubuntu can build ign-plugin from source if we make a release-tools PR
  • homebrew will need a ign-plugin formula
  • windows will probably need an update to the gazebodistro file: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebodistro/src/default/ign-physics0.yaml

content.raw:

update.description:
This PR presents the initial implementation of the Feature System. ~~I'm labeling it a WIP because I still want to add some more concrete tests and examples for how features work, but the implementation is finished, and I think it's safe to begin reviewing.~~

Note that this is the **FeatureSystem_raw** branch. The old `FeatureSystem` branch was a prototype which is being discarded (although it played a big role in getting this branch to where it is).

I recommend looking at `Feature_TEST.cc` to get a quick high-level glimpse of what the Feature System is trying to achieve. There are three mock "features": `EngineMockFeature`, `LinkMockFeature`, and `SecondLinkMockFeature`. Each of these defines a function within a nested class (`Engine` or `Link`). We create a `FeatureList` which combines all these features, and then use `Engine3d` and `Link3d`  to extract and combine their APIs. As a result, `Link3d<MockList>` contains both of the functions defined in `LinkMockFeature` and `SecondLinkMockFeature`.

~~My next step will be to add more concrete and illustrative tests to `Feature_TEST.cc`.~~

To see a full-fledged test use of the Feature System, see `test/integration/FeatureSystem.cc`.
update.title: Feature System

content.raw: This is a whole new level of off-by-one error.
content.html: This is a whole new level of off-by-one error.

content.raw:
Right, I expect that we’ll have a lot of pre-made feature implementations, where if a plugin provides features A and B, then it can inherit an implementation class to also get feature C for free. But if a plugin can implement feature C more efficiently than our pre-made approach \(for example, a physics engine might cache each model’s CoM calculation\), then it can use its internal implementation instead of our pre-made one.

Or if we want to get really fancy, we can make it so that when a user requests a feature from a plugin, then it will use that plugin’s implementation, but if the plugin doesn’t offer the implementation, then we’ll use the fallback implementation if the plugin provides the features required by the fallback.
content.html:
Right, I expect that we’ll have a lot of pre-made feature implementations, where if a plugin provides features A and B, then it can inherit an implementation class to also get feature C for free. But if a plugin can implement feature C more efficiently than our pre-made approach (for example, a physics engine might cache each model’s CoM calculation), then it can use its internal implementation instead of our pre-made one.

Or if we want to get really fancy, we can make it so that when a user requests a feature from a plugin, then it will use that plugin’s implementation, but if the plugin doesn’t offer the implementation, then we’ll use the fallback implementation if the plugin provides the features required by the fallback.

content.raw: We can use that variable name if you prefer it. The idea behind the current name is that `parentId[id]` will return the ID of the parent of `id`.
content.html: We can use that variable name if you prefer it. The idea behind the current name is that parentId[id] will return the ID of the parent of id.
